### \underline{Exercise 1}:

Assume that :

$$A = \begin{bmatrix}
3   &  0    &  3    \\
0   &  1    & -2    \\
3   & -2    &  8    \\
\end{bmatrix}
\quad 
B = \begin{bmatrix}
 2  & -1  &  b   \\
-1  &  2  & -1   \\
 b  & -1  &  2   \\
\end{bmatrix}
$$
Is $\textbf{A}$ positively defined? Are there values of $\textit{b}$ that matrix $\textbf{B}$ is positively defined? If yes what are those values?

### \underline{Solution}:

We know that a symmetrical matrix is positively defined if 

$$
\begin{equation}
\tag{1}
x^TAx > 0\quad \forall x \in \mathbb{R}^n,\quad x\neq 0
\end{equation}
$$
As a result, in order for a to be positively defined, we need to check whether the aforementioned equation $\textit{[1]}$ holds. As a result, all we have to do is check that.

$$
x^T A x \Leftrightarrow\\

\begin{bmatrix}
x_1   &  x_2    &  x_3 \\
\end{bmatrix}\times
\begin{bmatrix}
3   &  0    &  3    \\
0   &  1    & -2    \\
3   & -2    &  8    \\
\end{bmatrix} \times
\begin{bmatrix}
x_1 \\
x_2 \\
x_3 \\
\end{bmatrix} \Leftrightarrow \\

\begin{bmatrix}
3x_1 + 0x_2 + 3x_3 & 0x_1 + 1x_2 - 2x_3 & 3x_1 -2x_2 +8x_3 \\
\end{bmatrix}\times
\begin{bmatrix}
x_1 \\
x_2 \\
x_3 \\
\end{bmatrix} \Leftrightarrow \\

\begin{bmatrix}
(3x_1 + 3x_3)x_1 + (1x_2 - 2x_3)x_2 + (3x_1 -2x_2 +8x_3)x_3\\
\end{bmatrix} \Leftrightarrow\\

\begin{bmatrix}
3x_1^2 + 3x_1x_3 + x_2^2 - 2x_2x_3 + 3x_1x_3 - 2x_2x_3 +8x_3^2 \\
\end{bmatrix}\Leftrightarrow\\

\begin{bmatrix}
3x_1^2 + x_2^2 + 8x_3^2 + 6x_3x_1 - 4x_3x_2 \\
\end{bmatrix}\Leftrightarrow\\
$$
